title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

body.head: To Friends of the Monthly Meeting Committee appointed at Evesham Monthly Meeting the 7th of the 1st month 1785 to consider the advices of last Yearly Meeting.
body.p:
From a degree of that love and lively hope that accompanied our minds when at your Monthly Meeting & often revived since, we feel earnest desires that the cause righteousness may prosper your hands, and believe much depends on the proper discharge of the important trust committed to your care by the Monthly Meeting and felt easy to commit a few hints to writing, with much humility on our own accounts, yet strong desires for the promotion of the pure testimony in our day: and in order to be strong in this work, we believe it to be of absolute necessity that our own hands be in a degree clean from pollution of every kind, and especially from that which prompts the spirit, or defrays the expense of and it is our hope & belief that some who in time of weakness or darkness may have given way to pay requisitions of this kind, may yet come fruitfully to bear their pure testimony, in which we trust, faithful Friends, may be usefulness. Believing also that as deep thoughtfulness takes place, many things will appear for the honest-hearted to be exercised in; & to consider how far it consists with the plainness, simplicity, & purity of truth, to have or use in our families for furniture, or garments, calicoes, printed, stamped, or striped cloths, large scalloped and sometimes gilded frames for looking-glasses, with curling or carving on clock cases & other things, capes on men or women’s coats or cloaks; or suffering minor children to appear with highish bonnets, new fashioned gauze caps, scarlet coloured handkerchiefs, with spots, carved buckles, and other things, which close examination, perhaps we shall find that the purity of truth will not unite with: and how far our hands can be strong in treating with the youth under their libertine appearances, may be well to be deeply pondered by those who are entrusted with the weighty concerns of truth. From a lively hope that the pure testimony is as Likely to arise amongst you as in most places, we are encouraged to communicate these tender hints, hoping they may harm, and desiring honest care, and right
accompanied with true knowledge & meekness, may increase & abound among you, to your mutual comfort and joy, & to the increase of gospel fellowship & union.

closer.salute: We are your sincere friends, who crave to be your companions in the tribulations of our day & testimony,
closer.dateline: Wrote from Joseph Kaighn’s in Newtown Township the 12th of the 1st month 1788
